content: The Act is titled the "Civil War Sesquicentennial Commission Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. The American Civil War was a defining experience in the development of the United States. People continue to struggle with issues of race, civil rights, federalism, and heritage as legacies of the Civil War. There is a resurgence of interest in the Civil War with various publications, exhibits, reenactments, and research organizations. The years 2011-2015 mark the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, providing an opportunity for Americans to recall and reflect. The United States Civil War Center at Louisiana State University and the Civil War Institute at Gettysburg College have been designated to plan and facilitate the commemoration of the sesquicentennial of the Civil War. Virginia, with its numerous historic sites and museums, played a significant role in the Civil War. The African American Civil War Museum in Washington, DC is the only museum dedicated to African Americans' role in the Civil War. The purpose of the Act is to establish a Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission to ensure a national observance of the Civil War's 150th anniversary. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission aims to ensure an inclusive observance of the Civil War's 150th anniversary and support educational programs on the Civil War. The Secretary of the Interior will establish the Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission, referred to as the "Commission", to oversee the observance of the Civil War's 150th anniversary. The Commission, composed of 25 members, includes government representatives appointed by the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate, along with Secretaries of Interior, Smithsonian Institution, and Department of Education. The Commission, consisting of 25 members, includes government representatives appointed by the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate, along with Secretaries of Interior, Smithsonian Institution, and Department of Education. Additionally, private members appointed by the President include individuals representative of the corporate community and experts on the Antebellum, Civil War, and Reconstruction eras. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by government officials and the President, including experts on the Antebellum, Civil War, and Reconstruction eras. Members have expertise in history, art history, anthropology, cultural geography, sociology, political science, law, and economics. Appointments are for life, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission, consisting of 25 members with expertise in various fields, must be appointed within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Commission appointed under section 4 shall hold meetings within 60 days of all members being appointed. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson will be elected at the initial meeting. A majority of voting members constitutes a quorum, and decisions require an affirmative vote from the majority of voting members. The Commission appointed under section 4 shall hold meetings within 60 days of all members being appointed. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson will be elected at the initial meeting. Nonvoting members appointed under subparagraphs (A) and (B) of section 4(a)(1) serve only in an advisory capacity. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is responsible for planning and carrying out programs to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, encouraging interdisciplinary examination, facilitating related activities nationwide, coordinating scholarly research distribution, and providing technical assistance for commemoration efforts. The Commission is tasked with developing programs and facilities for the sesquicentennial commemoration of the Civil War, ensuring a positive legacy and involving the international community in related activities. They are also required to prepare strategic and annual performance plans, as well as submit reports on their activities. The Commission must submit an annual report to Congress listing gifts over $250 and their donors, and a final report by December 30, 2015, including a summary of activities, financial accounting, and recommendations. SEC. 7. GRANT PROGRAM. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award grants for activities related to the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, focusing on African American involvement. SEC. 8. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to solicit and accept gifts, appoint advisory committees, authorize members to take actions, procure supplies, and use the United States mails for its work. The Commission can accept gifts, appoint advisory committees, authorize members to take actions, procure supplies, and use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. SEC. 9. PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission and advisory committee members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director, whose employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission. The Chairperson can set the compensation for the executive director and other personnel without following certain provisions of the United States Code. The maximum rate of pay for the executive director and other personnel is capped at the rate payable for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist without interrupting civil service status. They can also accept voluntary services and the National Park Service will provide support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can request administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at specified rates. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior will conduct an annual audit of the Commission, with results made public. Authorization of appropriations includes $200,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2016 for Act implementation, and $3,500,000 for grants under section 7 to the National Endowment for the Humanities.
